commander.name: Generalleutnant Walther Nehring
commander.previous_service: Commander of 18. Panzer-Division on Eastern Front. Appointed DAK commander March 1942 after predecessor Cr체well captured by British
commander.notes: Seriously wounded in RAF air raid early September 1942 during Battle of Alam Halfa. Replaced by Generalleutnant Wilhelm Ritter von Thoma

Pz.Kpfw. III Ausf. J/L (5cm L/60).notes: Long-barrel 50mm gun, up-gunned 'Special' variant, effective anti-tank weapon

Pz.Kpfw. IV Ausf. F2/G (7.5cm L/43).notes: Long-barrel 75mm gun, critical for engaging British Grant and Sherman tanks at long range

Opel Blitz 3-ton.notes: Severe attrition from desert conditions and air attacks

10.5cm leFH 18.notes: Light field howitzer, standard divisional artillery

7.5cm PaK 40.notes: Excellent anti-tank gun, effective vs all British armor

Marder II.notes: Self-propelled 7.5cm PaK 40 on Panzer II chassis

8.8cm FlaK 18/36.note: Dual-purpose AA/AT gun, legendary effectiveness against British armor

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critically strained during July-September 1942. Mediterranean shipping losses severe - only 17,000 tons received in August vs 500,000 tons to British Eighth Army. Chronic fuel shortages constraining all mobile operations. DAK had only 3 days fuel for sustained combat during Battle of Alam Halfa (30 Aug - 5 Sept). Ammunition adequate but declining. Reliance on captured British vehicles and supplies critical for continued operations. Water rationing at 2.5-3 liters per man per day.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain and rocky desert at El Alamein position, firm ground suitable for armor operations

subordinate_units.commander: Generalmajor Georg von Bismarck (until 31 Aug KIA); Generalmajor Heinz von Randow (from Sept)

subordinate_units.notes: Transport, supply, maintenance, medical services. Includes corps HQ staff and support elements. Undermanned for desert logistics demands.

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armored exploitation and offensive operations in desert warfare. Primary mission: breakthrough operations with combined-arms panzer/panzergrenadier/artillery coordination. DAK was the core German armored striking force of Panzerarmee Afrika.
special_capabilities: Expert desert warfare tactics developed since 1941 (18+ months continuous combat)
Superior combined-arms coordination at regimental and divisional level
Effective use of 88mm FlaK guns in anti-tank role (Rommel innovation)
Highly mobile defensive tactics with rapid counterattack capability
Long-range tank gunnery superiority with Panzer IV Special and Panzer III Special
Flexible kampfgruppe organization for mission-specific task forces
tactical_innovations: Integration of FlaK batteries into mobile defense screens
Use of armored cars for deep reconnaissance in desert terrain
Kampfgruppe (battle group) organization for flexible task forces
Luring British armor onto defensive screens of AT guns and 88mm FlaK
Combined minefield and mobile reserve defense in depth
known_issues: CRITICAL: Chronic fuel shortages limiting operational mobility (only 3 days fuel during Alam Halfa offensive)
British air superiority restricting daylight movement and resupply
Long supply lines from Tripoli (1800km) vulnerable to interdiction by RAF and Royal Navy
Tank losses difficult to replace due to Mediterranean shipping losses
Tank strength greatly reduced: 229 total (183 operational) vs 150-200 per division authorized
Personnel exhaustion after 18+ months continuous desert combat
Vehicle attrition severe: operational readiness ~75-80% from desert wear and limited spare parts
Commander (Nehring) seriously wounded in RAF air raid early September 1942
Subordinate division commander (von Bismarck, 21. Panzer) KIA 31 August 1942
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive modifications for desert operations: sand filters for engines, additional water storage (critical constraint), desert camouflage schemes (tan/brown), tropical uniforms, sun protection gear, compass navigation equipment, extra fuel storage. All units are North Africa veterans with 18+ months experience by Q3 1942.

scenario_suitability: First Battle of El Alamein (1-27 July 1942) - defensive operations
Battle of Alam Halfa (30 Aug - 5 Sept 1942) - failed offensive
Mobile defense scenarios at El Alamein line
German panzer tactics vs British armoured formations
special_rules: Desert Warfare: +1 to movement in open desert, all units veteran of 18+ months North Africa combat
Veteran Crew: Tank crews may reroll failed morale checks
88mm Guns: +2 anti-tank effectiveness when dug in or deployed in defensive screens
Supply Constraints: -1 to all artillery attacks due to ammunition rationing
Fuel Crisis: -1 operational movement radius, limited pursuit capability
Air Interdiction: -1 to movement during daylight turns due to RAF air superiority
Combined Arms: +1 when panzer, panzergrenadier, artillery coordinate attacks
Tank Gunnery: +1 long-range tank vs tank with Panzer IV/III Specials
Rommel Doctrine: +1 when luring enemy armor onto AT gun/88mm screens
historical_engagements: First Battle of El Alamein (1-27 July 1942) - defensive, halted advance into Egypt
Battle of Alam Halfa (30 Aug - 5 Sept 1942) - offensive failed due to fuel shortages and British defense
Defensive preparations for Second El Alamein (September-October 1942)

source: Panzerarmee Afrika order of battle Q3 1942 (multiple historical sources)
Wehrmacht organizational records for Afrika Korps July-September 1942
First Battle of El Alamein order of battle (July 1942)
Battle of Alam Halfa order of battle (August-September 1942)
Generalleutnant Walther Nehring service record and command tenure
German divisional war diaries for North African campaign
DAK tank strength records August 1942 (229 German tanks total for DAK)
Mediterranean supply convoy records (severe losses documented)
Nafziger Collection - Afrika Korps organization Q3 1942
known_gaps: Exact corps HQ staff strength estimated based on typical German corps organization
Chief of Staff identity not confirmed in available sources
Some vehicle variant counts estimated from divisional allocations and typical corps assets
Corps-level support battalion designations incomplete beyond 605th (AT) and 606th (AA)
Precise tank variant distribution between divisions estimated from Battle of Alam Halfa data
Exact date of Nehring's wounding in September not specified (early September per sources)
Corps support units strength aggregated from typical German corps structure
